recipes.name: Poutine
ingredients: 4 large Russet Potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch thick fries
Salt and Black Pepper to taste
16 ounces fresh White Cheddar Cheese Curds, at room temperature
instructions: Prepare the Fries: Cut the potatoes into fries. Soak them in cold water for 30 minutes, then drain and pat dry.
Double-Fry the Fries: Heat oil to 325°F (160°C). Fry in batches for 5-7 minutes until soft. Remove and drain.
Increase oil to 375°F (190°C). Return fries and fry for 2-3 minutes until golden and crispy. Drain and season with salt.
Make the Gravy: Melt butter over medium heat. Whisk in flour and cook for 1 minute to create a roux.
Slowly whisk in beef broth until smooth. Simmer for 5-10 minutes until thickened. Stir in onion powder, salt, and pepper. Keep hot.
Assemble the Poutine: Divide hot fries among bowls. Sprinkle cheese curds generously over the fries. Ladle the piping hot gravy directly over the curds and fries. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Nanaimo Bars
ingredients: **Base:** 1/2 cup Unsalted Butter, 1/4 cup Granulated Sugar, 5 tablespoons Cocoa Powder, 1 large Egg (beaten), 1 teaspoon Vanilla Extract, 2 cups Graham Cracker Crumbs, 1 cup Shredded Coconut, 1/2 cup Finely Chopped Almonds
**Custard Filling:** 1/2 cup Unsalted Butter (softened), 2 cups Icing Sugar, 4 tablespoons Milk, 2 tablespoons Vanilla Custard Powder (Bird's brand)
**Topping:** 4 ounces Semi-Sweet Chocolate, 2 tablespoons Unsalted Butter
instructions: Prepare the Base: In a saucepan, melt 1/2 cup butter, sugar, and cocoa over low heat. Remove from heat, whisk in the beaten egg and vanilla, then cook for 1 minute until slightly thickened.
Assemble Base: Remove from heat. Stir in graham crumbs, coconut, and nuts. Press firmly into a parchment-lined 8x8 inch pan. Refrigerate for 15 minutes.
Make the Custard Filling: Cream the softened butter, icing sugar, milk, and custard powder until light and fluffy.
Layer the Filling: Spread the filling evenly over the chilled base. Refrigerate for 15 minutes.
Make the Topping: Melt the chocolate and 2 tablespoons butter together until smooth. Cool slightly.
Finish and Chill: Pour chocolate mixture over the custard layer. Chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours until the chocolate is firm. Cut into bars.

recipes.name: Classic Butter Tarts
ingredients: 12 unbaked Pie Tart Shells (or homemade pastry)
**Filling:** 1/2 cup Butter (melted), 1 cup Brown Sugar (packed), 1 large Egg (lightly beaten), 1/4 cup Corn Syrup or Maple Syrup, 1 teaspoon Vanilla Extract, 1/4 teaspoon Salt
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Place tart shells in a muffin tin.
Distribute raisins or pecans (if using) evenly across the bottom of the shells.
Make the Filling: In a bowl, combine melted butter, brown sugar, beaten egg, syrup, vanilla, and salt. Whisk until smooth.
Fill and Bake: Carefully pour the filling into the tart shells, filling them about two-thirds full. Do not overfill.
Bake for 15 to 18 minutes, or until the pastry is golden and the filling is bubbly and set (it will still be slightly soft in the center).
Cool for 10 minutes in the tin before carefully removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

recipes.name: Tourtière (French-Canadian Meat Pie)
ingredients: 1 pound Ground Pork (or a mix of pork and beef)
1 medium Potato, peeled and grated (optional, for texture)
2 sheets Pie Pastry (for a double-crust pie)
instructions: Make the Filling: Melt butter in a large skillet. Add onion and cook until soft, about 5 minutes.
Add the ground meat and cook, breaking it up with a spoon, until browned. Drain any excess grease.
Stir in the beef broth, cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Add the grated potato (if using). Bring to a simmer, cover, and cook for 15 minutes, allowing the liquid to mostly evaporate.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Assemble the Pie: Line a 9-inch pie plate with one sheet of pastry. Fill with the cooled meat mixture.
Top with the second pastry sheet. Crimp the edges to seal and cut a few slits in the top crust to allow steam to escape.
Bake for 60 to 70 minutes, or until the crust is golden brown. If the edges brown too quickly, cover them with aluminum foil.
Cool for at least 15 minutes before slicing and serving, traditionally with ketchup or cranberry sauce.

recipes.name: Split Pea Soup with Ham (Soupe aux pois)
ingredients: 1 cup Dried Green Split Peas, rinsed
1 cup Diced Ham or Ham Hock (about 8 oz)
instructions: Soak Peas (Optional): For faster cooking, soak split peas in cold water for 2 hours, then drain. If not soaking, cooking time will be longer.
Combine Ingredients: In a large, heavy-bottomed pot, combine the rinsed split peas, water or broth, diced ham, onion, celery, bay leaf, and thyme.
Bring to a Boil: Bring the mixture to a rapid boil over high heat, skimming off any foam that rises to the surface.

Simmer: Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and let the soup gently simmer for 1.5 to 2 hours, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking. The peas should break down and the soup will become thick and creamy.
Season and Serve: Remove the bay leaf. Season with salt and pepper to taste (salt carefully if using ham hock). If the soup is too thick, add a little water or broth. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Montreal Smoked Meat Sandwich
ingredients: 1 pound Montreal Smoked Meat (brisket), sliced thick
4 slices Dark or Light Rye Bread
instructions: Slice the Meat: Purchase pre-cooked Montreal smoked meat (brisket). Ensure it is sliced thick, similar to corned beef, but typically sliced by hand.

Steam the Meat: The authentic method is to steam the meat until it is piping hot. Place the slices in a steamer basket over boiling water, cover, and steam for 8-10 minutes. The internal temperature should be very hot.
Prepare the Bread: Lightly toast or steam the rye bread slices (steaming keeps them soft and warm).
Assemble the Sandwich: Spread a generous amount of yellow mustard on two slices of rye bread.
Stack the hot smoked meat high (at least 1/2 pound per sandwich) onto the mustard-coated bread slice. Top with the second slice of rye bread.
Cut and Serve: Slice the sandwich in half and serve immediately with a generous portion of dill pickles and often a side of fries or coleslaw.

recipes.name: Maple Taffy on Snow (Tire d'érable)
ingredients: 2 cups Pure Maple Syrup (Grade A Dark or Very Dark)
Clean, compacted Snow or Crushed Ice
instructions: Prepare Snow Bed: Fill a large, shallow baking dish or tray with clean, firmly packed snow or crushed ice. Create a few slight depressions or channels in the snow.
Heat Maple Syrup: Pour the pure maple syrup into a medium saucepan. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Do not stir, but watch carefully.
Cook to Temperature: Using a candy thermometer, heat the syrup until it reaches **235-240°F (113-116°C)** (the soft-ball stage).
Pour and Set: Immediately remove the saucepan from the heat. Carefully pour thin ribbons of the hot maple syrup directly onto the prepared snow bed.
Serve: Wait about 10-15 seconds for the taffy to cool and thicken. Use a wooden stick to roll the thickened taffy and lift it off the snow. Serve warm.

recipes.name: Newfoundland Jiggs Dinner
ingredients: 1 large Salt Beef/Salted Pork Hock (pre-soaked overnight)
1 cup Yellow Split Peas, tied tightly in a cloth bag ('Pease Pudding')
instructions: Soak and Simmer Meat: Soak the salted beef overnight in fresh water, changing the water once. Place the salt beef in a large pot and cover with fresh water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 2-3 hours.
Add Root Vegetables: Add the carrots, turnips, and the bag of split peas to the pot. Continue to simmer for 30 minutes.
Add Potatoes and Cabbage: Add the potatoes and quartered cabbage. Continue to simmer for another 30-45 minutes, or until all vegetables are fork-tender. The Pease Pudding should be very soft.
Cook Doughboys (Optional): If making doughboys, place them on top of the cooking vegetables for the last 15-20 minutes to steam.
Drain and Serve: Carefully drain most of the water from the pot. Remove the Pease Pudding bag and mash the peas. Slice the meat. Serve the meat, Pease Pudding, and vegetables on a large platter.

recipes.name: Bannock (Indigenous Fried Bread)
ingredients: 1/4 cup Shortening or Cold Butter, cut into pieces
Vegetable Oil or Lard, for frying/baking
instructions: Mix Dry Ingredients: In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt.
Cut in Fat: Cut the cold shortening or butter into the flour mixture using a pastry blender or your fingers until it resembles coarse crumbs.
Form Dough: Gradually add the warm water or milk, mixing until a shaggy dough forms. Do not overmix. The dough should be slightly sticky.

Shape and Cook: Divide the dough into 6 equal pieces. Bannock can be cooked three ways: **Baked:** Shape into flat rounds, bake at 375°F (190°C) for 20-25 minutes. **Pan-Fried:** Fry in a lightly oiled cast-iron skillet over medium heat for 5-8 minutes per side. **Deep-Fried:** Fry in 3 inches of oil at 350°F (175°C) until golden brown.
Serve: Serve warm with butter, jam, or as a side to soup or stew.

recipes.name: Caesar Cocktail (The Canadian Cocktail)
ingredients: Lemon or Lime Wedge, for rimming and garnish
Celery Stalk and/or Pickled Asparagus/Beans/Shrimp, for garnish
instructions: Rim the Glass: Run the lemon or lime wedge around the rim of a highball or large glass. Place celery salt on a small plate and dip the rim to coat.
Add Ice and Alcohol: Fill the glass with ice. Add vodka (if using).
Add Seasoning: Add the Worcestershire sauce, hot sauce, salt, and pepper. Adjust the amounts to your preferred spice level.
Top with Clamato: Top the glass with Mott's Clamato Juice.
Stir and Garnish: Stir gently to mix the ingredients. Garnish elaborately with a celery stalk, and any other favorite pickled garnishes (like pickled asparagus or beans). Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Newfoundland Toutons (Fried Bread Dough)
ingredients: 4 tablespoons Butter or Salt Pork Fat (Melted), for frying
instructions: Make Dough Base: In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, salt, and sugar. In a separate bowl, dissolve the yeast in the warm water and let stand for 5 minutes.

Mix Dough: Pour the yeast mixture into the flour mixture and stir until a soft, shaggy dough forms. Cover the bowl loosely with plastic wrap and let it rise in a warm spot until doubled in size (about 1 hour).
Shape: Punch down the dough and pinch off golf-ball sized pieces. Flatten each piece slightly into a round disc, about 1/2 inch thick.
Pan-Fry: Heat the butter or salt pork fat in a heavy-bottomed skillet over medium heat. Place the dough rounds in the hot fat, ensuring they are not crowded.
Cook: Fry for 3 to 5 minutes per side, or until they are golden brown and cooked through. They should puff up slightly.
Serve: Drain toutons on paper towels. Serve piping hot, traditionally drenched in unsulphured molasses.

recipes.name: BeaverTails (Queues de Castor)
ingredients: Topping: Melted Butter, Cinnamon Sugar (1/2 cup sugar mixed with 1 tbsp cinnamon)
instructions: Activate Yeast: In a large bowl, mix warm water, yeast, and a pinch of sugar. Let stand for 10 minutes until foamy.
Make the Dough: Stir in the remaining sugar, salt, and oil. Gradually add flour until a soft, slightly sticky dough forms.
Knead and Rise: Knead the dough on a floured surface for 5-7 minutes. Place in an oiled bowl, cover, and let rise for 60-90 minutes, or until doubled in size.
Shape and Fry: Punch down the dough and divide it into 6 pieces. Stretch or roll each piece into a long, flat oval (the 'beaver tail' shape).
Heat oil in a deep pot to 350°F (175°C). Fry the dough one at a time for about 1-2 minutes per side until golden brown. Remove and drain on paper towels.
Top and Serve: Brush the hot BeaverTails immediately with melted butter and sprinkle generously with cinnamon sugar. Serve warm.

recipes.name: Butter Chicken (Canadian Style)
ingredients: 1.5 lbs Boneless, Skinless Chicken Thighs, cut into cubes
**Marinade:** 1 cup Plain Yogurt, 1 tbsp Ginger-Garlic Paste, 1 tsp Turmeric, 1 tbsp Garam Masala
**Sauce:** 2 tbsp Butter, 1 large Onion (pureed), 1 can (14 oz) Crushed Tomatoes, 1 cup Heavy Cream, 1 tbsp Sugar, 1 tsp Kasuri Methi (dried fenugreek leaves)
instructions: Marinate Chicken: Combine chicken cubes with all marinade ingredients. Cover and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes, or up to 4 hours.
Sear Chicken: Heat 1 tbsp of oil in a large pot or Dutch oven. Add the chicken (shake off excess marinade) and cook in batches until browned on all sides. Set aside.
Make the Sauce Base: Melt 2 tbsp butter in the same pot. Add the pureed onion and cook until lightly browned (5-7 minutes). Add the remaining ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Build the Sauce: Stir in the remaining spices (garam masala, turmeric), then add the crushed tomatoes, sugar, and a little salt. Bring to a simmer and cook for 10 minutes.

Finish the Dish: Return the seared chicken to the sauce. Stir in the heavy cream and crushed Kasuri Methi. Simmer gently for 10-15 minutes until the chicken is cooked through and the sauce is rich. Serve hot with basmati rice or naan bread.

recipes.name: Ginger Beef (Chinese-Canadian)
ingredients: 1 lb Flank Steak, cut into thin strips
**Coating:** 1 Egg White, 1/4 cup Cornstarch, 1/4 cup All-Purpose Flour
**Sauce:** 1/2 cup Beef Broth, 1/4 cup Rice Vinegar, 2 tbsp Soy Sauce, 2 tbsp Brown Sugar, 1 tbsp Cornstarch, 1/4 tsp Chili Flakes
**Aromatics:** 3 tbsp Fresh Ginger (julienned), 2 cloves Garlic (minced), 1/2 Red Bell Pepper (julienned), 1 stalk Green Onion (sliced)
instructions: Coat the Beef: Whisk the egg white. Toss the beef strips in the egg white, then dredge them in a mixture of flour and cornstarch until fully coated.
Fry the Beef: Heat 2 inches of oil in a wok or deep skillet to 350°F (175°C). Fry the beef strips in small batches for 3-4 minutes until golden brown and crispy. Drain and set aside.
Make the Sauce: In a small bowl, whisk together all the sauce ingredients until the cornstarch is dissolved.
Stir-Fry Aromatics: Drain the oil, leaving about 1 tbsp in the wok. Add the julienned ginger and garlic and stir-fry for 30 seconds until fragrant. Add the red bell pepper and cook for 2 minutes.
Combine: Pour the sauce mixture into the wok and cook, stirring until the sauce thickens and bubbles (about 1 minute).
Finish: Return the crispy beef to the wok. Toss quickly to coat everything evenly in the sauce. Stir in the green onion and serve immediately over steamed rice.

recipes.name: Montreal Bagels (Sesame Seed)
ingredients: 2 tablespoons Honey or Malt Syrup (in dough)
**Boiling Water:** 1/4 cup Honey or Malt Syrup (in boiling water)
instructions: Make Dough: Mix water, yeast, 1 tbsp honey/malt syrup, egg, and salt. Gradually mix in the flour to form a stiff dough. Knead for 10-15 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Rise: Place in an oiled bowl, cover, and let rise until doubled (60-90 minutes).
Shape: Punch down the dough and divide it into 12 pieces. Roll each piece into a rope and wrap it around your hand to form a circle, sealing the ends together to create a large hole in the center.
Boil: Preheat oven to 450°F (230°C). Bring a large pot of water to a boil and add 1/4 cup honey/malt syrup. Boil the bagels for 30 seconds per side.
Seed and Bake: Remove from water, drain well. Immediately dip both sides into sesame seeds. Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet.
Bake: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes, flipping halfway through, until deeply golden brown and crispy. Serve fresh with cream cheese or smoked salmon.

recipes.name: Butter Tart Ice Cream
ingredients: **Mix-in:** 4 Pre-made Butter Tarts (pecan or plain), crumbled
instructions: Prepare the Base: In a medium saucepan, combine heavy cream, milk, 1/2 cup of the sugar, and salt. Heat over medium heat just until steaming.

Temper the Egg Yolks: In a separate bowl, whisk the egg yolks with the remaining 1/4 cup sugar until pale. Slowly ladle about 1 cup of the hot cream mixture into the yolks, whisking constantly to temper them.
Cook Custard: Pour the tempered yolk mixture back into the saucepan. Cook over low heat, stirring constantly, until the custard thickens enough to coat the back of a spoon (175°F or 80°C).
Chill: Remove from heat, stir in vanilla. Strain the custard into a clean bowl, cover, and chill thoroughly in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours, or overnight.
Churn and Mix-in: Churn the chilled custard base in an ice cream maker according to the manufacturer's directions. In the last 5 minutes of churning, add the crumbled butter tart pieces.
Swirl and Freeze: Transfer the ice cream to an airtight container. Drizzle the maple syrup over the top and gently swirl with a knife. Freeze for at least 4 hours until firm.

recipes.name: Wild Blueberry Grunt
ingredients: **Fruit:** 4 cups Fresh or Frozen Wild Blueberries, 1/2 cup Granulated Sugar, 1/4 cup Water, 1 teaspoon Lemon Juice
**Dumplings:** 1 cup All-Purpose Flour, 2 tablespoons Granulated Sugar, 2 teaspoons Baking Powder, 1/2 teaspoon Salt, 1/2 cup Milk, 2 tablespoons Melted Butter
instructions: Prepare Fruit Base: In a wide, deep saucepan or Dutch oven, combine the blueberries, 1/2 cup sugar, water, and lemon juice. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a gentle simmer. Cover and cook for 5 minutes.
Prepare Dumplings: While the berries simmer, whisk together the flour, 2 tbsp sugar, baking powder, and salt in a bowl. Add the milk and melted butter and stir just until combined (do not overmix).
Add Dumplings: Drop the dumpling batter by spoonfuls directly onto the simmering blueberry mixture. They should sit on top of the berries, not sink into the liquid.

Steam: Cover the pot tightly with a lid (the lid must be secure for steaming). Reduce the heat to low and let the grunt steam for 20 to 25 minutes. **Do not lift the lid during this time.** The steam cooks the dumplings.
Serve: The dumplings should be puffed and firm. Serve immediately in bowls, spooning the warm berry sauce over the top. Traditionally served with vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.

recipes.name: Peameal Bacon Sandwich
ingredients: 4-6 slices Peameal Bacon (cured, rolled pork loin, often coated in cornmeal)
1 Kaiser Roll or Bun, sliced horizontally
Mustard (Honey Mustard or Dijon are common)
instructions: Cook Peameal Bacon: Peameal bacon is usually sold uncooked. Pan-fry the slices in a lightly oiled skillet over medium heat for 3-5 minutes per side, or until cooked through and lightly browned. It should not be crispy like regular bacon.
Prepare the Bun: While the bacon cooks, split the Kaiser roll. You may optionally toast or butter it on a griddle.
Assemble: Spread mustard generously on both sides of the Kaiser roll.
Stack the peameal bacon slices high onto the bottom half of the bun (4-6 slices is typical for a full sandwich).
Serve: Top with the other half of the bun and serve hot. Additional toppings like cheese or a fried egg are optional but less traditional.

recipes.name: Schmoo Torte
ingredients: **Cake:** 3 large Egg Whites, 1/2 cup Sugar, 1 tsp Vanilla, 1 cup Chopped Pecans (or walnuts), 1 cup Graham Cracker Crumbs, 1 tsp Baking Powder
**Topping:** 3 large Egg Yolks, 1/2 cup Brown Sugar, 1/2 cup Butter, 1 cup Heavy Cream (whipped), 1 tsp Vanilla
instructions: Make the Base Cake: Preheat oven to 325°F (160°C). Beat egg whites until stiff peaks form, gradually adding sugar. Fold in vanilla, nuts, graham crumbs, and baking powder.
Bake: Pour mixture into a greased and floured 9-inch round pan. Bake for 35-45 minutes until golden. Cool completely and remove from pan.

Make the Caramel Sauce: In a small saucepan, melt the butter and brown sugar. Cook until bubbling. Whisk in the egg yolks quickly and cook for 1 minute until thickened. Remove from heat and stir in vanilla. Cool completely.
Whip Cream: Beat the heavy cream until soft peaks form.

Assemble: Place the cooled cake layer on a serving plate. Spread the cooled caramel sauce over the cake. Top generously with the whipped cream. Cover and chill for at least 6 hours, or overnight, to allow the flavors and textures to blend.

recipes.name: Caesar Salad (Canadian Version)
ingredients: 1 large head Romaine Lettuce, washed and torn
**Dressing:** 1/2 cup Olive Oil, 1 Egg Yolk, 2 cloves Garlic (minced), 1 teaspoon Dijon Mustard, 1 teaspoon Worcestershire Sauce, 2 Anchovy fillets (mashed), 1/2 Lemon (juiced), Salt and Pepper
instructions: Prepare Dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together the egg yolk, mashed anchovies, minced garlic, Dijon mustard, Worcestershire sauce, and lemon juice. Season with salt and pepper.
Emulsify: Slowly drizzle in the olive oil while continuously whisking until the dressing thickens and emulsifies. Alternatively, blend all dressing ingredients in a food processor.
Prepare Salad: Place the torn romaine lettuce in a large mixing bowl.
Dress and Toss: Pour the dressing over the lettuce. Add most of the grated Parmesan cheese and half of the croutons. Toss gently to coat the lettuce thoroughly.
Serve: Serve immediately on chilled plates. Garnish with the remaining croutons and a final dusting of Parmesan cheese.

recipes.name: Rappie Pie (Pâte à la Râpure)
ingredients: 10 lbs Potatoes (Russet or similar), peeled and grated
4 cups Cooked Chicken or Pork, shredded
5-6 cups Chicken or Pork Broth (boiling hot)
1/2 cup Rendered Fat (chicken or pork fat)
instructions: Process Potatoes: Finely grate all the potatoes (using a food processor or hand grater). Place the grated potato pulp in cheesecloth and squeeze out as much liquid as possible. Reserve the liquid.
Extract Starch: Let the reserved potato liquid sit for 15 minutes, allowing the starch to settle at the bottom. Pour off the liquid, leaving the dense white starch behind.
Make the Dough (Râpure): In a very large bowl, combine the dry potato pulp and the extracted starch. Mix well.
Add Broth: Slowly pour the boiling hot broth into the potato mixture while stirring vigorously. The mixture should become a very thick, sticky paste (the râpure). Season with salt and pepper.

Assemble and Bake: Grease a large baking dish (about 9x13 inches) with the rendered fat. Spread half of the râpure mixture into the dish. Layer the shredded, cooked meat and chopped onions on top. Cover with the remaining râpure.
Bake: Pour a small amount of fat or butter on top. Bake in a preheated oven at 350°F (175°C) for 3 hours, or until a dark, crispy crust forms and the center is set.

recipes.name: Timbits (Doughnut Holes)
instructions: Mix Dry Ingredients: Whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg in a large bowl.
Mix Wet Ingredients: In a separate bowl, combine the beaten egg, milk, and melted butter.

Combine and Knead: Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir until just combined. The dough will be soft and sticky. Knead lightly on a floured surface, if needed, just to bring it together.
Shape Doughnuts: Roll the dough to about 1/2 inch thickness. Use a small, round cutter or simply pinch off small balls of dough to form the holes.
Fry: Heat oil in a deep pot to 375°F (190°C). Carefully drop the dough balls into the hot oil (do not overcrowd). Fry for 2-3 minutes, turning occasionally, until they are golden brown all over.
Coat: Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. While still warm, toss them in icing sugar, or dip them in a simple sugar glaze (powdered sugar + milk).

recipes.name: Oka Cheese Fondue
ingredients: 1 cup Dry White Wine (e.g., Sauvignon Blanc)
1 pound Oka Cheese (semi-soft, washed-rind), rind removed and shredded
Dippers: Cubes of French bread, baby potatoes, or apples
instructions: Prepare the Pot: Rub the inside of a heavy-bottomed pot (or fondue pot) with the cut sides of the garlic clove. Discard the garlic.
Heat Wine: Pour the white wine into the pot and bring to a gentle simmer over medium-low heat (do not boil).
Thicken Cheese: Toss the shredded Oka cheese with the cornstarch in a separate bowl until fully coated. This prevents clumping.
Melt Cheese: Gradually add the cheese mixture to the simmering wine, handful by handful, stirring constantly in a figure-eight motion until all the cheese is melted and the fondue is smooth.
Finish and Serve: Stir in the Kirsch (if using) and a pinch of nutmeg. Transfer the fondue to a warm fondue pot set over a low flame. Serve immediately with bread cubes and other dippers.

recipes.name: Maritimes Fish Cakes
ingredients: 1 pound Salt Cod or Flaked White Fish (Haddock or Pollock), cooked
1 cup Mashed Potatoes (made with butter and milk)
Serve with: Ketchup or Chow-Chow Relish
instructions: Prepare Fish and Potatoes: Ensure the cooked fish is fully flaked and boneless. The mashed potatoes should be cold and firm (using leftover mashed potatoes is ideal).
Mix Patties: In a large bowl, combine the flaked fish, mashed potatoes, chopped onion, parsley, lemon juice, and pepper. Mix until just combined; do not overmix.

Shape and Chill: Divide the mixture and form into 8-10 uniform patties, about 1 inch thick. Place the patties on a plate and chill in the refrigerator for at least 15 minutes to help them hold their shape.
Pan-Fry: Melt the butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Fry the fish cakes in batches for 5-7 minutes per side, or until they are golden brown and crispy on the outside and heated through.
Serve: Serve hot, often topped with a traditional Maritime relish like Chow-Chow, or simple ketchup.

recipes.name: Tiger Tail Ice Cream
ingredients: **Base:** 2 cups Heavy Cream, 1 cup Whole Milk, 3/4 cup Granulated Sugar, 4 large Egg Yolks, 1 teaspoon Vanilla Extract
**Orange Base Flavour:** 1 tablespoon Orange Extract, 1/2 teaspoon Orange Food Colouring (optional)
**Black Licorice Swirl:** 1/2 cup Black Licorice Syrup (or simple syrup with licorice extract and black food coloring)
instructions: Prepare Orange Base: In a medium saucepan, create a vanilla custard base using the cream, milk, sugar, and egg yolks (cook to 175°F/80°C to thicken). Stir in vanilla extract, orange extract, and food coloring (if using).
Chill: Strain the custard, cover, and chill thoroughly in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours, or overnight.
Churn: Churn the chilled orange custard base in an ice cream maker according to the manufacturer's directions.
Prepare Swirl: While the ice cream churns, prepare the licorice syrup, ensuring it is cool. (The syrup should be black and have a strong licorice flavour).

Swirl and Freeze: Transfer the churned ice cream to an airtight container, alternating layers of ice cream with drizzles of the black licorice syrup. Use a butter knife to create a tiger-stripe swirl pattern. Freeze for at least 4 hours until firm.

recipes.name: Matrimonial Date Squares (Date Crumbles)
ingredients: **Base/Topping:** 1 cup All-Purpose Flour, 1 cup Rolled Oats (not instant), 1 cup Brown Sugar (packed), 1/2 teaspoon Baking Soda, 1/2 cup Cold Butter (cubed)
**Filling:** 2 cups Chopped Dates, 1 cup Water, 1/4 cup Granulated Sugar, 1 tablespoon Lemon Juice
instructions: Prepare the Date Filling: In a medium saucepan, combine the chopped dates, water, sugar, and lemon juice. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring until the dates soften and break down into a thick paste. Cool completely.

Prepare the Crumble: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). In a large bowl, mix the flour, oats, brown sugar, and baking soda. Cut in the cold butter using a pastry blender or your fingers until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Layer and Bake: Press half of the crumble mixture firmly into the bottom of a greased and parchment-lined 8x8 inch square baking pan.
Spread the cooled date filling evenly over the base layer.
Sprinkle the remaining crumble mixture evenly over the date filling.
Bake for 35 to 40 minutes, or until the topping is golden brown. Cool completely in the pan before cutting into squares.

recipes.name: Meat Ball Stew (Fricot à la Boulette)
ingredients: 1.5 lbs Ground Beef and/or Pork mix
1 teaspoon Savory (dried spice, essential to Acadian cooking)
instructions: Prepare Meatballs: In a large bowl, gently mix the ground meat, chopped onion, bread crumbs, egg, salt, pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon of the dried savory. Do not overmix. Roll the mixture into small, uniform meatballs (about 1.5 inches).
Make Broth Base: Pour the chicken broth into a large pot or Dutch oven. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to a gentle simmer.
Cook Meatballs: Carefully drop the raw meatballs into the simmering broth. Cook for 15 minutes, skimming off any foam that rises.
Add Vegetables and Seasoning: Add the cubed potatoes and the remaining 1/2 teaspoon of dried savory. Bring the stew back to a simmer.
Simmer: Cover and cook for 45-60 minutes, or until the potatoes are tender and the meatballs are fully cooked. The starch from the potatoes will naturally thicken the stew. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Hodgepodge (Maritimes Fresh Vegetable Stew)
instructions: Cook Potatoes and Carrots: In a large pot, combine the potatoes and carrots with water or broth. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 10 minutes until slightly tender.

Add Beans and Peas: Add the green beans and peas to the pot. Continue to simmer for another 5-7 minutes, until all vegetables are fork-tender. Drain most of the cooking liquid, reserving about 1/2 cup.
Finish the Sauce: Return the pot to the stove on low heat. Stir in the butter until melted. Pour in the heavy cream (or milk) and the reserved cooking liquid.
Season and Serve: Heat gently for 2-3 minutes until the liquid is warmed through and thickened slightly (do not boil). Season generously with salt and pepper. Stir in fresh parsley and serve warm.

recipes.name: Garlic Fingers (Nova Scotia Flatbread)
ingredients: 1 batch Pizza Dough (enough for a large rectangular pan)
Dipping Sauce: Donair Sauce (see Recipe #7) or Marinara Sauce
instructions: Prepare Dough: Once the pizza dough has risen, press or roll it out to fit a large (13x9 inch) baking sheet. Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C).
Add Garlic Butter: In a small bowl, whisk together the melted butter, minced garlic, and oregano.
Assemble: Brush the garlic butter mixture evenly over the surface of the dough. Cover the entire surface generously with shredded mozzarella cheese.
Bake: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes, or until the crust is golden brown and the cheese is melted and bubbling.
Cut and Serve: Remove from the oven. Using a pizza cutter, slice the flatbread into long strips or 'fingers.' Serve immediately while hot, with a side of Donair Sauce for dipping.

recipes.name: Blueberry Grunt (Steamed Dumpling Dessert)
ingredients: **Fruit:** 4 cups Fresh or Frozen Wild Blueberries, 1/2 cup Granulated Sugar, 1/4 cup Water, 1 teaspoon Lemon Juice
**Dumplings:** 1 cup All-Purpose Flour, 2 tablespoons Granulated Sugar, 2 teaspoons Baking Powder, 1/2 teaspoon Salt, 1/2 cup Milk, 2 tablespoons Melted Butter
instructions: Prepare Fruit Base: In a wide, deep saucepan or Dutch oven, combine the blueberries, 1/2 cup sugar, water, and lemon juice. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a gentle simmer. Cover and cook for 5 minutes.
Prepare Dumplings: While the berries simmer, whisk together the flour, 2 tbsp sugar, baking powder, and salt in a bowl. Add the milk and melted butter and stir just until combined (do not overmix).
Add Dumplings: Drop the dumpling batter by spoonfuls directly onto the simmering blueberry mixture. They should sit on top of the berries, not sink into the liquid.

Steam: Cover the pot tightly with a lid (the lid must be secure for steaming). Reduce the heat to low and let the grunt steam for 20 to 25 minutes. **Do not lift the lid during this time.** The steam cooks the dumplings.
Serve: The dumplings should be puffed and firm. Serve immediately in bowls, spooning the warm berry sauce over the top. Traditionally served with vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.

recipes.name: Tarte au Sucre (Sugar Pie)
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Place the pie shell on a baking sheet.
Prepare Filling: In a large bowl, whisk together the brown sugar, flour, and salt until there are no lumps.
Mix Wet Ingredients: In a separate bowl, whisk the heavy cream (or evaporated milk), melted butter, vanilla extract, and egg (if using) until combined.
Combine and Fill: Pour the wet mixture into the dry ingredients and whisk until smooth. The mixture will be thin.
Pour the filling carefully into the unbaked pie shell.
Bake: Bake for 35 to 45 minutes, or until the edges are set and lightly browned, and the center still has a slight jiggle. If the crust edges brown too quickly, cover them with foil.
Cool: Cool completely on a wire rack before serving. The pie filling will set as it cools. Traditionally served plain or with a little whipped cream.

recipes.name: Oka Cheese Croque Monsieur
ingredients: 4 slices Thick White Bread (Brioche is ideal)
**Béchamel Sauce:** 2 tablespoons Butter, 2 tablespoons All-Purpose Flour, 1 cup Whole Milk, Pinch of Nutmeg, Salt and Pepper
instructions: Make Béchamel: Melt butter in a saucepan. Whisk in flour and cook for 1 minute. Gradually whisk in the milk until the sauce thickens. Season with nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Set aside.
Assemble Sandwich: Lightly toast the bread. Spread Dijon mustard on two slices. Layer ham slices and half of the Oka cheese slices on the mustard-coated bread. Top with the remaining bread slices.
Sauce and Cheese Topping: Spread a thin layer of Béchamel sauce over the top of each sandwich. Top with the remaining Oka cheese slices.

Bake/Broil: Place the sandwiches on a baking sheet. Bake in a preheated oven at 400°F (200°C) for 5-7 minutes, then switch to the broiler for 1-2 minutes until the cheese topping is melted, bubbly, and golden brown. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Creton (French Canadian Pork Pâté)
ingredients: 1 pound Ground Pork (or ground pork shoulder)
Salt and Black Pepper to taste
instructions: Combine Ingredients: In a medium saucepan, combine the ground pork, milk, water, chopped onion, cloves, and cinnamon. Season generously with salt and pepper.

Cook Mixture: Bring the mixture to a simmer over medium heat, stirring to break up the pork. Reduce heat to low and simmer gently, uncovered, for about 60-90 minutes, stirring occasionally. The liquid should mostly evaporate, and the mixture should resemble a wet paste.
Thicken: Stir in the dry bread crumbs during the last 15 minutes of cooking. Continue to stir until the mixture thickens slightly. Remove from heat.

Chill and Set: Transfer the creton mixture into small ramekins or a terrine dish. Smooth the top. Cover tightly with plastic wrap (press the wrap directly onto the surface to prevent a crust from forming).
Refrigerate for at least 6 hours, or overnight, until fully set. Serve chilled, spread on toast or crackers.

recipes.name: Fried Cod Tongues
ingredients: 1 pound Fresh Cod Tongues (the fleshy part below the jaw)
1/4 cup Pork Scrunchions (rendered salt pork fat, diced) or Butter, for frying
Serve with: Lemon wedges and Scrunchions
instructions: Clean and Prepare: Rinse the cod tongues and pat them completely dry. In a shallow dish, combine the flour, salt, and pepper.
Coat: Dredge the cod tongues lightly in the seasoned flour mixture, shaking off any excess.
Render Fat: In a large, heavy skillet, melt the butter or render the salt pork scrunchions over medium-high heat until the fat is hot (remove the crispy pork pieces if using butter).

Fry: Add the floured cod tongues to the hot fat, ensuring they are not crowded. Fry for 5 to 7 minutes per side, turning once, until they are golden brown and crispy on the outside and cooked through.
Serve: Drain on paper towels. Serve immediately with a squeeze of fresh lemon and often topped with the crispy pork scrunchions, if reserved.

recipes.name: Classic Butter Tart Sauce (Topping)
ingredients: 1/4 cup Corn Syrup or Maple Syrup
instructions: Melt Base: In a medium saucepan, combine the butter, brown sugar, heavy cream (or evaporated milk), and corn syrup (or maple syrup).
Bring to Simmer: Place over medium heat, stirring constantly until the butter is melted and the sugar is dissolved. Bring the mixture to a gentle simmer.
Cook: Reduce the heat to low and let the sauce simmer for 5-7 minutes without stirring, allowing it to thicken slightly. Watch carefully to prevent scorching.
Finish: Remove from heat. Stir in the vanilla extract and a pinch of salt.
Serve: Serve warm as a topping for ice cream, pancakes, waffles, or other desserts. Store cooled sauce in the refrigerator; it will solidify and may need gentle reheating before serving.

recipes.name: Yellow Mustard Slaw
ingredients: Salt and Black Pepper to taste
instructions: Prepare Vegetables: In a large bowl, combine the shredded cabbage and grated carrot. Pat them dry slightly if they are very wet.
Make the Dressing: In a separate medium bowl, whisk together the mayonnaise, yellow mustard, sugar, white vinegar, and celery seed until the sugar is dissolved and the dressing is smooth.
Combine and Season: Pour the dressing over the cabbage and carrot mixture. Toss gently but thoroughly until all the vegetables are coated.

Chill: Season generously with salt and pepper to taste. Cover the bowl and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes (or up to 4 hours) to allow the flavours to meld and the cabbage to soften slightly. Toss again just before serving.

recipes.name: Flapper Pie
ingredients: **Custard Filling:** 1/2 cup Granulated Sugar, 1/4 cup All-Purpose Flour, 1/4 teaspoon Salt, 2 large Egg Yolks, 2 cups Whole Milk, 1 teaspoon Vanilla Extract
**Meringue Topping:** 2 large Egg Whites (room temp), 1/4 cup Granulated Sugar, 1/4 teaspoon Cream of Tartar
instructions: Make Custard: In a saucepan, whisk together the sugar, flour, and salt. Whisk in the milk and egg yolks until smooth. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the custard thickens to a pudding consistency (about 8-10 minutes). Remove from heat and stir in vanilla.
Fill Crust: Pour the warm custard filling into the prepared graham cracker crust. Let cool slightly while preparing the meringue.
Make Meringue: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Beat the egg whites and cream of tartar until soft peaks form. Gradually add the sugar, beating until stiff, glossy peaks form.

Top and Bake: Spread the meringue over the warm custard filling, ensuring the meringue touches the crust edges all around to prevent shrinking. Bake for 10-12 minutes until the meringue is lightly golden brown.
Chill: Cool the pie completely at room temperature, then chill in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours before serving.

recipes.name: Acadian Ployes (Buckwheat Pancakes)
ingredients: 1/4 teaspoon Baking Soda, dissolved in a splash of warm water (essential)
Serve with: Butter, Molasses, or Creton
instructions: Mix Dry Ingredients: In a large bowl, whisk together the buckwheat flour, all-purpose flour (if using), baking powder, and salt.
Mix Batter: Gradually whisk in the cold water until a smooth, thin batter forms (it should be runnier than typical pancake batter).
Activate Soda: Stir the dissolved baking soda into the batter. This step activates the leavening and is critical to ploye texture.
Cook: Heat a large, flat, **ungreased** cast-iron griddle or non-stick pan over medium-high heat. The pan must be hot.

Pour and Cook: Pour about 1/4 cup of batter onto the hot pan. Ployes are traditionally cooked on one side only. Cook until the surface is covered in bubbles and the top is dry (3-5 minutes). Do not flip.
Serve: Remove with a spatula. Serve immediately, stacked, with butter and molasses or savory spreads.

recipes.name: Maple Salmon
ingredients: 4 Salmon Fillets (6 oz each, skin on or off)
1/4 cup Pure Maple Syrup (Grade A Dark or Very Dark)
1 tablespoon Soy Sauce (or Tamari for gluten-free)
instructions: Prepare Marinade/Glaze: In a small bowl, whisk together the maple syrup, Dijon mustard, soy sauce, minced garlic, ginger powder, salt, and pepper.
Marinate (Optional): Place the salmon fillets in a shallow dish and pour half of the glaze over them. Marinate for 10-15 minutes (no longer, as the acid can 'cook' the fish).
Cook: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C) or preheat grill to medium-high.
Bake: Place the salmon (skin side down) on a foil-lined baking sheet or grill surface. Brush liberally with the remaining glaze.
Bake/Grill for 12 to 15 minutes, depending on thickness, until the salmon flakes easily with a fork. You may finish under the broiler for 1 minute to caramelize the top. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Figgy Duff
ingredients: 1 cup Raisins (historically, no actual figs are used)
1/2 cup Beef Suet (or cold butter, chopped)
instructions: Prepare Steamer: Fill a large stockpot with water about halfway and bring it to a boil. Place a trivet or steamer basket inside.
Mix Dry Ingredients: In a large bowl, combine the flour, baking soda, ginger, and cinnamon.
Cut in Fat: Cut the suet or cold butter into the flour mixture until it resembles coarse crumbs.
Add Wet Ingredients: Stir in the brown sugar, raisins, molasses, and milk until just combined. Do not overmix.
Steam: Spoon the batter into a pudding cloth, pillowcase, or a large, heavily greased, heatproof bowl (like a Pyrex bowl). Cover the top tightly with foil and tie it securely with kitchen twine.

Cook: Place the bowl on the trivet in the boiling water. The water should come about halfway up the bowl. Cover the pot and steam for 3 hours, ensuring the water level remains consistent (refill with boiling water as needed).
Serve: Carefully remove the pudding from the pot. Let it cool slightly, then invert it onto a serving plate. Serve warm, often with a simple hard sauce or custard.
